text:
Union Square East, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of 15th Street.  The corner building is the Union Square Hotel.

1890
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 15th Street.

folder: Union Square (East) & Between 15th and 18th Streets (North)., Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square East, north from and including 15th Street, to but not including 18th Street. In the foreground is seen Union Square.

June 2, 1904.

Brown Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 15th and 18th Streets (North).

text:
Union Square East, north from and including 15th Street (Fourth Ave, as shown is a continuation of Union Square East).

About 1913.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 15th Street.

text:
Union Square Hotel, Union Square East on S.E. corner of 15th Street, with adjoining buildings on 15th Street and on Union Square East, newly remodelled by S. Klein for his growing business.
The Union Square Hotel was built late in the 1870's on the site of the old residences 14-16-18 Union Square. The 15th Street wing of the S. Klein's enlarged quarters was made by remodelling the newer Hotel America. In the background may be seen the tower of the new Consolidated Gas Building at Irving Place and 14th Street, completed 1928.

August 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 15th Street.

text:
Union Square Savings Bank, Union Square East at N.E. corner of 15th Street, with part of the newly remodelled park in the foreground. This edifice was built some time between 1902 and 1910, replacing two old houses; the bank had its original offices in 20 Union Square, on the corner. The 9-story apartment house at 107 East 15th Street, adjoining the bank, was built about 1900.

August 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 15th Street.

folder: Union Square (East) & Between 15th and 16th Streets., Manhattan, NY
text:
Neg. No. 223 =

(1)
24, 26-8, and 30 Union Square, between 15th and 16th Streets, occupied by the Polish daily Novy Swiat ("The New World"), The Daily Worker (organ of the Communist Party), and the radical Jewish Freiheit ("Freedom"). These buildings, except possibly 24, are business buildings built on the site of the original houses, probably around 1880. They may be located on the Edison Company's photograph of Union Square in 1893. The Daily Worker has only moved in since 1928. All these buildings will, before 1933, be taken over and remodelled by S. Klein as a store for higher-priced dresses. At the time of this picture, the Co-operative Cafeteria pictured here was the regular hangout of the Communist organizers, much as Luchow's Restaurant on 14th Street used to be (and still is) frequented by district leaders from mammany Hall. August 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Neg. No. 223 a+b

(2)
The same, earlier the same year.
February 20, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 15th and 16th Streets.

title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 15th and 16th Streets.

folder: Union Square (East) & Between 15th and 16th Streets., Manhattan, NY
text:
20-34 Union Square East, from 15th to 16th Streets, with a portion of the park (which was drastically remodelled, 1929-30) in the foreground. The Union Square Savings Bank, 20-22 Union Square on the 15th Street corner, was erected between 1902 and 1910. The 11-story Reliance Building was also erected at the same time, replacing an old 4-story house. 34 Union Square on the corner of 16th Street, was built prior to 1890.
Old 24, 26-8, and 30 have been taken over since 1930 and remodelled by S. Klein; another story has been added to 24. See 1930 views of these three buildings.

P. L. Sperr.
February 24, 1933.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 15th and 16th Streets.

folder: Union Square (East) & Between 15th and 17th Streets (East)., Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square East, north from East 15th (right) to 17th Streets, showing the crowds thronging the streets at this focal point during the May Day Parade. This is a set of 3 views, No. 2 of which shows a further view northward on Fourth Ave. (same as Union Square East when north of East 17th Street).

May 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 15th and 17th Streets (East).

title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 15th and 17th Streets (East).

text:
Peddlers, food, fruit: An apple vendor on Union Square East at 15th Street during the May Day Parade. Note the groups in Union Square; the southern termination of the line of march.

May 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Occupations - Peddlers - Food - Fruit.
